DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of acute myeloid leukemia classification.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001)_A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia
Concepts.definition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).

Property.preferredDefinition: Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.longName: Classification
Concepts.definition: A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001)._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute basophilic leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Basophilic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare acute myeloid leukemia in which the immature cells differentiate towards basophils.

Concepts.longName: Acute Basophilic Leukemia
Concepts.definition: A rare acute myeloid leukemia in which the immature cells differentiate towards basophils.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with MLLT3::KMT2A fusion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(9;11)(p22.3;q23.3); MLLT3-KMT2A
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(9;11)(p22.3;q23.3) and MLLT3-KMT2A fusion protein expression. Morphologically it usually has monocytic features. It may present at any age but it is more commonly seen in children. Patients may present with disseminated intravascular coagulation.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3); MLLT3-KMT2A
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3) and MLLT3-KMT2A fusion protein expression. Morphologically it usually has monocytic features. It may present at any age but it is more commonly seen in children. Patients may present with disseminated intravascular coagulation.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition and VM Long Name_ghd_11.16.16

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with other KMT2A rearrangements

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with MLL Rearrangement
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by rearrangement of the MLL (mixed-lineage leukemia) gene. It affects infants, children and adults. It is usually associated with poor prognosis.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with KMT2A Rearrangement
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by rearrangement of the KMT2A gene. It affects infants, children and adults. It is usually associated with poor prognosis.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with DEK::NUP214 fusion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(6;9)(p23;q34.1); DEK-NUP214
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(6;9)((p23;q34.1) resulting in DEK-NUP214(CAN) fusion protein expression. It is often associated with multilineage dysplasia and basophilia. It affects both children and adults and it usually has an unfavorable clinical outcome.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(6;9)(p22.3;q34.1); DEK-NUP214
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(6;9)(p22.3;q34.1) resulting in DEK-NUP214(CAN) fusion protein expression. It is often associated with multilineage dysplasia and basophilia. It affects both children and adults and it usually has an unfavorable clinical outcome.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition and VM Long Name_ghd_11.16.16

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with MECOM (EVI1), GATA2 rearrangement

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(3)(q21.3;q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2); GATA2, MECOM
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with inv(3)(q21.3q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2) resulting in the reposition of a distal GATA2 enhancer to activate MECOM expression. It may present de novo or follow a myelodysplastic syndrome. The clinical course is aggressive.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(3)(q21.3;q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2); GATA2, MECOM
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with inv(3)(q21.3q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2) resulting in the reposition of a distal GATA2 enhancer to activate MECOM expression. It may present de novo or follow a myelodysplastic syndrome. The clinical course is aggressive.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition and VM Long Name_ghd_11.16.16

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with Other MECOM rearrangements

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with a Variant MECOM Rearrangement
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term referring to acute myeloid leukemias with rearrangement of the MECOM gene with various genes other than the GATA2 gene.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with a Variant MECOM Rearrangement
Concepts.definition: A term referring to acute myeloid leukemias with rearrangement of the MECOM gene with various genes other than the GATA2 gene.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with RBM15::MRTFA fusion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.3); RBM15-MKL1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.3) resulting in the expression of RBM15-MKL1 fusion protein. It affects infants and children and usually shows megakaryocytic maturation.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1); RBM15-MKL1
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1) resulting in the expression of RBM15-MKL1 fusion protein. It affects infants and children and usually shows megakaryocytic maturation.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition and VM Long Name_ghd_11.16.16

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(8;21)(q22;q22); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) showing maturation in the neutrophil lineage.  The bone marrow and the peripheral blood show large myeloblasts with abundant basophilic cytoplasm, often containing azurophilic granules.  This type of AML is associated with good response to chemotherapy and high complete remission rate.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(8;21)(q22; q22.1); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with t(8;21)(q22; q22.1) giving rise to RUNX1/RUNX1T1 fusion transcript and showing maturation in the neutrophil lineage. The bone marrow and the peripheral blood show large myeloblasts with abundant basophilic cytoplasm, often containing azurophilic granules. This type of AML is associated with good response to chemotherapy and high complete remission rate.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with CBFB::MYH11 fusion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(16)(p13.1q22); CBFB-MYH11
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the presence of abnormal bone marrow eosinophils and the characteristic cytogenetic abnormality inv(16)(p13.1q22) which results in the expression of the fusion protein CBFB-MYH11.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(16)(p13.1q22); CBFB-MYH11
Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the presence of abnormal bone marrow eosinophils and the characteristic cytogenetic abnormality inv(16)(p13.1q22) which results in the expression of the fusion protein CBFB-MYH11.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia with t(15;17)(q22;q12); PML-RARA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate.  It is characterized by the t(15;17)(q22;q12) translocation.  There are two variants: the typical and microgranular variant.  This AML is particularly sensitive to treatment with all trans-retinoic acid and has a favorable prognosis.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia with t(15;17)(q24.1;q21.2); PML-RARA
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate. It is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion. There are two variants: the typical and microgranular variant.  This AML is particularly sensitive to treatment with all trans-retinoic acid and has a favorable prognosis. (WHO)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute promyelocytic leukemia with other RARA fusions

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with a Variant RARA Rearrangement
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term referring to acute myeloid leukemias which show variant translocations involving the RARA gene.  The variant fusion partners include NUMA1, ZBTB16, STAT5B, and NPM1.  These leukemias often have the morphologic features of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with a Variant RARA Rearrangement
Concepts.definition: A term referring to acute myeloid leukemias which show variant translocations involving the RARA gene.  The variant fusion partners include NUMA1, ZBTB16, STAT5B, and NPM1.  These leukemias often have the morphologic features of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with BCR::ABL1 fusion

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with BCR-ABL1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare, de novo acute myeloid leukemia in which the blasts harbor BCR-ABL1 translocation in the absence of a history and clinical and laboratory features of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with BCR-ABL1
Concepts.definition: A rare, de novo acute myeloid leukemia in which the blasts harbor BCR-ABL1 translocation in the absence of a history and clinical and laboratory features of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with NPM1 mutation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated NPM1
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the nucleophosmin gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and frequently has myelomonocytic or monocytic features. It usually responds to induction therapy.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with NPM1 Mutation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with mutation of the nucleophosmin gene. It is usually associated with normal karyotype and frequently has myelomonocytic or monocytic features. It usually responds to induction therapy.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with CEBPA mutation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Biallelic Mutations of CEBPA
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with double mutations of the CEBPA gene.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Biallelic CEBPA Mutation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with double mutations of the CEBPA gene.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with myelodysplasia - related

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Myelodysplasia-Related Changes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia with at least 20% blasts in the bone marrow or blood, and either a previous history of myelodysplastic syndrome, multilineage dysplasia or myelodysplastic syndrome-related cytogenetic abnormalities.  There is no history of prior cytotoxic therapy for an unrelated disorder, and there is absence of the cytogenetic abnormalities that are present in acute myeloid leukemia with recurrent genetic abnormalities.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia, Myelodysplasia-Related
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with at least 20% blasts in the bone marrow or blood, and either a previous history of myelodysplastic syndrome, multilineage dysplasia or myelodysplastic syndrome-related cytogenetic abnormalities.  There is no history of prior cytotoxic therapy for an unrelated disorder, and there is absence of the molecular abnormalities that are present in acute myeloid leukemia with recurrent genetic abnormalities.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with NUP98 rearrangement

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with NUP98 Rearrangement
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by rearrangement of the NUP98 gene with various genes.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with NUP98 Rearrangement
Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by rearrangement of the NUP98 gene with various genes.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with mutated TP53

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated TP53
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the presence of TP53 gene mutations. There are 20% or more blasts in bone marrow or peripheral blood.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Mutated TP53
Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the presence of TP53 gene mutations. There are 20% or more blasts in bone marrow or peripheral blood.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with other defined genetic alterations

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Recurrent Genetic Abnormalities
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) characterized by recurrent genetic abnormalities, mainly balanced translocations.  This group of AMLs often has a high rate of complete remission, and favorable prognosis.  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Recurrent Genetic Abnormalities
Concepts.definition: A group of acute myeloid leukemias characterized by recurrent genetic abnormalities, mainly balanced translocations.  (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with minimal differentiation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia, Minimally Differentiated
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which the blasts do not show evidence of myeloid differentiation by morphology and conventional cytochemistry. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Minimal Differentiation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in which the blasts do not show evidence of myeloid differentiation by morphology and conventional cytochemistry. (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia without maturation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute myeloblastic leukemia, without maturation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils.  The patients present with anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.  This type of AML usually follows an aggressive clinical course.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia without Maturation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts without evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia with maturation

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute myeloblastic leukemia, with granulocytic maturation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts with evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. Patients often present with anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. AML with the t(8;21) is usually AML with maturation. This type of AML frequently responds to aggressive therapy. (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Maturation
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by blasts with evidence of maturation to more mature neutrophils. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myelomonocytic leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute leukemia characterized by the proliferation of both neutrophil and monocyte precursors.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia
Concepts.definition: An acute leukemia characterized by the proliferation of both neutrophil and monocyte precursors.  (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute monocytic leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Monocytic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which the majority of monocytic cells are promonocytes.  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.longName: Acute Monocytic Leukemia
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which the majority of monocytic cells are promonocytes.  (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute erythroid leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute erythroid leukemias, including erythroleukemia (M6a) and very rare pure erythroid leukemia (M6b)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by a predominant immature erythroid population.  There are two subtypes recognized: erythroleukemia and pure erythroid leukemia.  Severe anemia is a common symptom.  This leukemia usually follows an aggressive clinical course.  (WHO, 2001)

Concepts.longName: Acute Erythroid Leukemia
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by a predominant immature erythroid population.  There are two subtypes recognized: erythroleukemia and pure erythroid leukemia. (WHO, 2001)

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

PermissibleValues.value: Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which at least 50% of the blasts are of megakaryocytic lineage.  The prognosis is usually poor.  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.longName: Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia
Concepts.definition: An acute myeloid leukemia in which at least 50% of the blasts are of megakaryocytic lineage. (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.value: Myeloid sarcoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Myeloid Sarcoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tumor mass composed of myeloblasts or immature myeloid cells.  It occurs in extramedullary sites or the bone.  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.longName: Myeloid Sarcoma
Concepts.definition: A tumor mass composed of myeloblasts or immature myeloid cells.  It occurs in extramedullary sites or the bone.  (WHO, 2001)

PermissibleValues.value: Acute myeloid leukemia, not otherwise specified

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Not Otherwise Specified
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acute myeloid leukemias that do not fulfill the criteria for inclusion in the group of acute myeloid leukemias which have recurrent genetic abnormalities or myelodysplastic changes, or are therapy-related.  This category includes entities classified according to the French-American-British classification scheme.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Not Otherwise Specified
Concepts.definition: Acute myeloid leukemias that do not fulfill the criteria for inclusion in the group of acute myeloid leukemias which have recurrent genetic abnormalities or myelodysplastic changes, or are therapy-related.  This category includes entities classified according to the French-American-British classification scheme.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.longName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia
Concepts.definition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).

Concepts.longName: Type
Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: Artificial Neural Network Algorithm for BRIDG Mapping

ReferenceDocuments.name: PQT
ReferenceDocuments.description: What was the classification of the acute myelogenous leukemia?

ReferenceDocuments.name: BRIDG mapping path for CDE:2682630
ReferenceDocuments.description: PerformedDiagnosis.value(ANY=>CD).translation(CD).code WHERE PerformedDiagnosis.value(ANY=>CD).code = "Acute Myelogenous Leukemia(AML)" OR "acute nonlymphocytic leukemia" AND PerformedDiagnosis.value(ANY=>CD).translation(CD).codeSystem = "WHO classification"
